title: 110_hr3648
content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Additionally, the amount excluded from gross income reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income if discharged before January 1, 2010. This exclusion reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Additionally, certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition are exempt from this provision. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income if discharged before January 1, 2010. The act specifies that the principal residence exclusion takes precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income if discharged before January 1, 2010. The act specifies that the principal residence exclusion takes precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. The amendment applies to amounts paid or accrued after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation, including requirements related to gross income, property usage, and expenditures. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act, regarding expenses for the corporation's property benefiting tenant-stockholders. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and payments. Deductions and expenses are subject to limitations to avoid double benefits. Definitions for qualified state and local tax benefits are provided. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions or rebates provided by a State or political division for services performed as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization. A 'qualified payment' is any payment for such services, limited to $30 per month. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization providing firefighting or emergency medical services, required by a written agreement to furnish such services in a State or political subdivision. This section does not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2010. Section 139B provides benefits to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Section 6 clarifies that single parents and their children, who are not dependents of another individual, are eligible for low-income housing credit. The amendment in Section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date. It also addresses the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion in post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. Section 121(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a surviving spouse to substitute $500,000 for $250,000 in the case of a sale within 2 years of their spouse's death. This amendment applies to sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S Corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries is added to section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment to section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code limits the disclosure of taxpayer identity information to only the entity making the return or the person conducting the inspection. The effective date of this amendment is the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6699 imposes penalties for failure to file S Corporation returns under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 6699 imposes penalties for failure to file S Corporation returns under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. S corporations failing to file returns or providing incomplete information under section 6037 are subject to penalties of $85 per month per shareholder, up to 12 months, unless reasonable cause is shown. SEC. 6699 imposes penalties for failure to file S Corporation returns under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation based on the number of shareholders during the taxable year. Deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. SEC. 6699 imposes penalties for failure to file S Corporation returns under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to returns required to be filed after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, the percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points with respect to certain dates.
